title: 111_s1964
content: The "Mutual Fund Transparency Act of 2009" requires disclosure of financial relationships between brokers, dealers, and mutual fund companies. The "Mutual Fund Transparency Act of 2009" mandates brokers and dealers to disclose compensation received for transactions involving mutual funds, unit investment trusts, and municipal securities used for education savings plans. The "Mutual Fund Transparency Act of 2009" requires investment advisers to disclose any compensation, including payments to brokers or dealers, related to promoting the sales of securities. Disclosure must be provided to customers by the completion of the transaction. The Mutual Fund Transparency Act of 2009 mandates disclosures of compensation related to promoting securities sales, with limitations on where disclosures can be made and a deadline for the Commission to issue final rules within a year of enactment. The Mutual Fund Transparency Act of 2009 requires disclosures in a specified format determined by the Commission. Definitions for terms like 'open-end company' and 'closed-end company' are provided, along with the meaning of 'unit investment trust' and 'education savings plan'. The Mutual Fund Transparency Act of 2009 mandates disclosure of brokerage commissions as part of fees and expenses for open-end or closed-end companies, unit investment trusts, or issuers of municipal securities. The Commission will require disclosure of brokerage commissions as an aggregate dollar amount and percentage of assets paid in the 5-year period preceding the transaction in registration statements and other filings with the Commission. SEC. 3. MUTUAL FUND GOVERNANCE. Section 10(a) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to require independent fund boards to have 25 percent interested persons, elect a chairman from the registered company, and have non-interested persons approved by shareholders every 5 years. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to require independent directors to have no conflicts of interest with the company or its service providers, ensuring their independence. The Investment Company Act of 1940 now mandates that independent directors of registered investment companies must establish a committee of non-interested members to select nominees and set qualification standards for directors. These standards must be disclosed in the company's registration statement. The Investment Company Act of 1940 requires independent directors of registered investment companies to establish a committee of non-interested members to select nominees and set qualification standards for directors. The definition of an Interested Person under the Act has been amended to include natural persons who have served as officers, directors, or employees of investment advisers or principal underwriters within the preceding 10 fiscal years. The definition of an Interested Person under the Investment Company Act of 1940 has been expanded to include individuals who have served as officers, directors, or employees of entities that have provided significant services to registered investment companies in the past 5 years. Additionally, individuals who are part of a group deemed unlikely to be independent by the SEC due to business relationships are also considered Interested Persons. The definition of an Interested Person under the Investment Company Act of 1940 has been expanded to include individuals with significant business relationships with the investment company or its affiliates, close familial relationships with affiliated persons, or for any other reason determined by the Commission. Additionally, the number of individuals considered Interested Persons has been increased from two to five, and individuals who are members of a group deemed non-independent due to business relationships are also included. The definition of an Interested Person under the Investment Company Act of 1940 has been expanded to include individuals with significant business relationships with the investment company or its affiliates, close familial relationships with affiliated persons, or for any other reason determined by the Commission. The Commission may also consider individuals who are members of a group deemed non-independent due to business relationships. The Investment Company Act of 1940 has expanded the definition of an Interested Person to include individuals with significant business relationships with the investment company or its affiliates, close familial relationships with affiliated persons, or for any other reason determined by the Commission. The Commission will issue final rules defining the term 'significant service provider' within 270 days of the enactment of the Mutual Fund Transparency Act of 2009. The Investment Company Act of 1940 expands the definition of an Interested Person to include individuals with significant business relationships with the investment company or its affiliates. The Commission will define the term 'significant service provider' within 270 days of the Mutual Fund Transparency Act of 2009. Paragraph (1) must include the investment adviser and principal underwriter of a registered investment company for paragraph (19) purposes. SEC. 4. FINANCIAL LITERACY AMONG MUTUAL FUND INVESTORS STUDY. The Securities and Exchange Commission will conduct a study to identify the level of financial literacy among investors purchasing shares of open-end companies, the necessary information for sound financial decisions, methods to increase transparency of expenses and conflicts of interest, existing efforts to educate investors, and a strategy to improve investor financial literacy and behavior. The Securities and Exchange Commission will submit a report to the Senate and House Committees on Banking and Financial Services one year after enacting a study on investor behavior. SEC. 5. STUDY REGARDING MUTUAL FUND ADVERTISING. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on mutual fund advertising, including regulatory requirements, marketing practices, consumer impact, and recommendations for improving investor protections. A report on the study results must be submitted within 1 year of the Act's enactment. The study results will be reported to the Senate's Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs and the House's Committee on Financial Services. SEC. 6. POINT-OF-SALE DISCLOSURE. Section 15(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to require brokers and dealers to disclose compensation details to buyers of certain securities. Brokers and dealers are required to disclose compensation details received in connection with transactions, including the amount in dollars and as a percentage of assets, comparative information on average amounts received by brokers, and any other relevant information as determined by the Commission. The term 'compensation' includes payments made by investment advisers to promote sales of securities of a registered investment company. Disclosures must be made before the transaction to allow evaluation by the purchaser. The disclosures cannot be made exclusively in certain ways. The Mutual Fund Transparency Act of 2009 prohibits certain disclosures in registration statements or filings of registered investment companies. The Commission is required to establish final rules within one year. Additionally, a new subsection in the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 addresses fiduciary duties and sets a standard of care for investment advisers. The Mutual Fund Transparency Act of 2009 mandates the Commission to establish rules within one year to ensure that brokers and dealers providing investment advice to retail customers act in the best interest of the customer, following the fiduciary duty set by the Investment Advisers Act of 1940.
